instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.C7125: What is C7125? Capacitor between CHGR_BOOT and CHGR_PHASE important for bootstrapping creation of PPBUS_G3H on 2013-2015 macbook pros.
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG? This is battery power that flows to the system AFTER it has gone through a current sense resistor, before it goes through a fuse to become PPBUS_G3H power rail. .
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.PLT_RESET_L: What is PLT_RESET_L? PLT_RESET_L is platform reset, this signal keeps the system from POSTing. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A with no power. It has green light, and no fan spin.

I have no hiustory about it.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 1.821V, and 0.156 on diode reading.

Already tried new DC board, and new charger.

Can you help?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Post <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> basic voltages; pins 1, 2, 3, 9, 12, 13, 15, 17, 19, 20, 27.
Check resistance between pins 17/18 and 27/28.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Remove F7140 and check <CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR> voltage.

You may need to change <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>.
Be sure <CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> is good; check its traces too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C7140</CAPACITOR> has 8.57V,  without F7140.
<CAPACITOR>C7125</CAPACITOR> seams to be OK, and the traces are OK.

Changing <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR> had the same result.

With F7140 soldered <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> cames back to 1.8V

Should I inject voltage on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> to check for heat? It has 0.178 on diode reading.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
No need to change <TRANSISTOR>Q7130</TRANSISTOR>, if get correct voltage without F7140.
Check diode mode to ground on all coils; compare with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> is shorted. 0.20 diode  to ground, checked on L7520, and it had a bit of corrosion under L7520. The comparison diode mode to ground is 0.340.
Can inject 1V to check what component is shorted?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
After inject voltage on  <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> , I notice that <CHIP>U7600</CHIP> was getting hot, and so I've replaced it. Now <SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> has 0.430 on diode to ground reading, but still no power on, and  <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 1.8V again.

L7630 has the same diode resistance to ground has <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>  (0.130)

L7320 has 0.014

L7310 has 0.014

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message: Check diode mode between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and any coil.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Diode mode between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and L7130 / L7630 is 0.001.

Btween other coils it has values around 0.400, except L7320 and L7310 witch is 0.220

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
"Diode mode between <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> and ... L7630 is 0.001"
And you still applied power on the board.
"Check diode mode to ground on all coils; [B][U]compare with <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>[/U][/B]."
Pay more atention when you read the posts.

Change <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi,

After replacing <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>, the short is gone. However, the mac tries to boot, has fan spin, reaches 0.650A and powers off (10mA).
Alreay tried new CLEAN ME without success
Any idea?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
PCH is bad probably.

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes high?
Did you try SMC bypass?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Hi.

<SIGNAL>PLT_RESET_L</SIGNAL> goes to 3.3V and then 0V

SMC bypass has the same result.

Do you think it is PCH?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A no power
threads.message:
Overvoltage went to PCH for sure, throuh <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>.
Sometime it survives; seems is not the case here.
